Mar 11, 2020 Tattooed Bibliophile rated it it was amazing
Genre: Children's Fantasy

Rating: MG*

"Harry, yer a wizard."

This is only my second read of Harry Potter. I read them as they started coming out in the US 1998. It's one of those series that I never re-read because I was terrified that it would ruin the magic, that I wouldn't love it as much as I did the first time around.

But my kids are old enough now to read them, and when the illustrated versions came out, I decided it was time to pick one up for a bedtime story.

And I have to say, it's even Genre: Children's Fantasy

Rating: MG*

"Harry, yer a wizard."

This is only my second read of Harry Potter. I read them as they started coming out in the US 1998. It's one of those series that I never re-read because I was terrified that it would ruin the magic, that I wouldn't love it as much as I did the first time around.

But my kids are old enough now to read them, and when the illustrated versions came out, I decided it was time to pick one up for a bedtime story.

And I have to say, it's even more fun this time, watching their faces in awe of flying on brooms and dragon eggs and three-headed giant dogs named Fluffy.

In addition, it's so interesting to know what's going to happen and watch as J.K. drops hints to what's really going on and seeing how Harry and Hermione and Ron follow breadcrumbs to the wrong conclusions. The first time was like a puzzle without the picture, watching it come to life, but this time, knowing what the picture will be in the end, I get to watch as each piece of plot drops perfectly into place. It's a different experience, but still an amazing one.

And my kids. They adore it. Even the three-year old, who calls it "Harry Cotter," listens avidly and wants me to stop so he can "ooo and ahhh" over each gorgeously detailed illustration.

My only regret is that Minalima is now coming out with Harry Potter books, and I don't know if I'll like those better or these!

5 stars, because duh.

*I've heard some parents concern that with themes of death and magic that they are afraid the books are too mature for their kids. While each parent has to judge that for themselves, I found the books to be less "scary" than the movies that picture Voldemort as quite a terrifying figure. My 6 and 7 year olds handled the concepts well.

Mar 05, 2019 Jemima Ravenclaw rated it it was amazing
Shelves: z2019d-april, book-club-reads-2019, my-5-star-favourites, format-audible, genre-children-s-classic, theme-debut, list-essential-ya-teen-and-preteen, genre-fantasy, type-fiction, format-on-my-home-bookshelf
In some ways this is a difficult review to write. It is the first installment of a book series whose characters grew in age, confidence and self determination over the years, as I also grew in these characteristics, and was a touch stone at many different points of my young adult life. Naturally a book that starts such a journey is always going to be a five star read.

I first encountered this book a year after it was first published, when I was teaching violin lessons to children to help fund In some ways this is a difficult review to write. It is the first installment of a book series whose characters grew in age, confidence and self determination over the years, as I also grew in these characteristics, and was a touch stone at many different points of my young adult life. Naturally a book that starts such a journey is always going to be a five star read.

I first encountered this book a year after it was first published, when I was teaching violin lessons to children to help fund myself through a degree in Nursing, after deciding that spending my life as a financially and egotistically insecure musician was not a career I wished to pursue. I had been a highly successful violin teacher for a number of years, but the loss of my birth family through points of moral difference as well as my controversial decision to not pursue a career as a performer, pushed me into abandoning my first degree at the Conservatorium of Music and to finally get the Nursing Degree, that I had wanted all along. I give this personal background because I think it explains how a 23 year old girl could find such immediate link of sympathy and warmth from delving into J.K. Rowling's story about an unwanted child, who is marginalized for perceived and comparative failures since birth and for being different. Harry did not fit in easily anywhere. He was both too weird and strange with talents that set him aside from others in the muggle world, as well as not being outstanding enough, or talented enough to meet the expectations of those who lived in the wizarding world, where he is famous and revered for something he does not even remember doing. He is disliked and feared by his blood family and grows up not knowing what approval, acceptance and unconditional love feel like.

I purchased 'Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone' the week I observed at least two families who came for violin lessons have to strongly persuade their avidly reading child to hand over their book and start their lesson. Once the lesson commenced, the parent in both cases grabbed up the book and began to read it themselves. Of course, I enquired about the book immediately. I was always deeply interested in what was important to my students, and on their encouragement, I went and purchased the book for myself. Fortunately for me, the second installment of the series was only weeks away from publication, but afterwards there began the long and anxious wait for each new installment, made slightly more bearable by sharing this experience with fans from all over the world, courtesy of the new internet and particularly 'The Leaky Cauldron' fan site.

Ron, Harry and Hermione, the Weasley family and the teachers at Hogwarts became very real to me and were such a comfort when life became too isolating or difficult. The happy end to my story is that in the same year I met Harry Potter for the first time, I also became engaged and then soon after married to the love of my life, who looked awfully like Ron Weasley, but is definitely more like a male version of Hermione. I now have two young teen boys who are as passionate about Harry Potter as I am and with whom I continue to share our own unique version of the Wizarding World in our own little home. I am more like a full time Molly Weasley these days, and frequently wish for a magic wand to help me get through my busy day a little more easily. I did become a very successful, qualified paediatric ‚ÄôHealer‚Äô, skills that served me well when my youngest was born with a condition that required expert nursing care. These days I play in a community Symphony Orchestra and friends' weddings just for the joy of it and teach my kids the skills I worked so hard to learn myself, but without the emotional pressure.

This was J,K. Rowling's debut novel, written during the hardest point in her own life where destitution and abandonment were also knocking on her door. With each novel in the series, the age of the children and the maturity and complexity of the themes and their grows significantly. Issues are explored which draw many parrallels with our own world and our shared human history. If you feel that this is only a light hearted series written for children about magic, it would be worthwhile for you to take deeper look at the many themes addressed in this book series. It is widely credited with significantly influencing a generation of readers who on psychological testing display unusual amounts and of empathy, social awareness and value the principals of acceptance and justice to an unusual degree in what may be called 'The Harry Potter Generation'. ...more

Jan 11, 2013 Darlene rated it it was amazing
Shelves: books-i-own, bought, read-alouds, read-in-2013, 2013-dusty-bookshelf-challenge, 2013-literary-exploration-challenge
This was a re-read for me. Caught up in the excitement of all the rave reviews, I read this one when it first came out. I devoured it then, and I was anxious to read more of the series. However, I decided that this was exactly the type of series that I wanted to experience with my children (I didnt even have any at the time!) and turned a blind eye to all the future releases in the series as well as the movies. I did not want to spoil the joy of sharing something so wonderful with my kids.

I read This was a re-read for me. Caught up in the excitement of all the rave reviews, I read this one when it first came out. I devoured it then, and I was anxious to read more of the series. However, I decided that this was exactly the type of series that I wanted to experience with my children (I didn‚Äôt even have any at the time!) and turned a blind eye to all the future releases in the series as well as the movies. I did not want to spoil the joy of sharing something so wonderful with my kids.

I read this aloud to my children, and they loved it as much as I did! Rowling writes in such a way that the book can be enjoyed by young and old alike. It transcends generations.

For anyone who has been living on another planet and not yet heard about this phenomenal book, it is about a 10 year-old boy named Harry Potter. He was orphaned as a babe and left to be raised by his maternal Aunt Petunia and Uncle Vernon, who do not care for him one bit. While they lavish attention on their dear Dudley, they treat Harry as though he isn‚Äôt worthy of any love. He is treated like a servant, made to do the cooking and cleaning, and given crumbs to eat. His ‚Äúroom‚Äù is the cupboard under the stairs, even though spoiled Dudley has two bedrooms for himself: One for his bed and the other for his toys.

A mysterious envelope arrives addressed to Harry. Before he has a chance to open it, Uncle Vernon snatches it away when he sees the seal on the envelope is from a place named Hogwarts. More envelopes arrive, and Uncle Vernon boards up the mail slot and burns the mail. Finally, he takes the family away to a secluded island away from anyone for miles around. It occurs on the day of Harry‚Äôs 11th birthday, which of course is not celebrated by the Dursley family. A giant of a man breaks down the door and introduces himself as Rubeus Hagrid, who presents Harry with one of the elusive envelopes. It turns out that Harry has been accepted into Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, which is located in a parallel magical world. Hagrid further informs Harry that his parents were also witches who were killed by a bad warlock named Voldemort. This is all a shock to Harry, as he had been told that his parents died in a car crash. For some reason, Voldemort was unable to bring harm to Harry save for the lightning bolt-shaped scar on his forehead. After Voldemort‚Äôs inability to destroy Harry, he disappeared. Some say he died, and others say that he is still around just biding his time. Harry became famous among the witches because he is the only one who was able to survive a tangle with the evil Voldemort.

Harry goes with Hagrid to Hogwarts, where he enters his first year of training to become a wizard. He makes friends with two other first-year students: Ronald Weasley, a red-haired boy who comes from a lower-class family of witches and is frowned upon by some of the richer class because of his hand-me-down robes and books, and Hermione Granger, a bushy brown-haired girl who also has trouble fitting in because she comes from a non-magical ‚ÄúMuggle‚Äù family (Muggles are known as non-magical folks.) At first, Hermione comes across as a know-it-all because she is extremely smart and studious. Later, after she takes the blame for an incident which saves Ron and Harry from getting into trouble, the three become inseparable.

Hogwarts itself is fantastically magical with its talking portraits, staircases that change at will, secret passageways, and a forbidden forest. The place is filled with mystery, and Harry and his friends are just beginning their journey of discovery.

This is the type of book that I would have loved as a child. It is a classic tale of good versus evil. I love that Rowling incorporates some life lessons about social classes. When Ron is taunted by the richer wizard families (Draco Malfoy and his two sidekicks, Gregory Goyle and Vincent Crabbe) for his family‚Äôs meagre wealth, Harry stands up for him. Harry is envious of what Ron has, which is a loving family. That means more to him than all the wealth in the world, and he would give anything for it.

My kids and I are so excited to continue with the next book in the series, Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets. ...more

Feb 03, 2019 Katy Nicole rated it it was amazing
Shelves: owned
Favorite Quote(s): "To a well organized mind, death is but the next great adventure."

Review:
First off, if you don't really know what this is, I'm forced to believe that you are either an alien or someone who has been held captive underground for the last 30 years and recently escaped.

I had this recommended to me about 3427946972364723 times growing up and I never touched it purely because I just didn't think it would be something I would be into. I had only read cute little standalones. The only Favorite Quote(s): "To a well organized mind, death is but the next great adventure."

Review:
First off, if you don't really know what this is, I'm forced to believe that you are either an alien or someone who has been held captive underground for the last 30 years and recently escaped.

I had this recommended to me about 3427946972364723 times growing up and I never touched it purely because I just didn't think it would be something I would be into. I had only read cute little standalones. The only real series I had read that had this much hype behind it was twilight. Which I loved. I pretty much just rebelled against the Harry Potter phenomenon.



However, I went to the local flea market and stumbled on a tiny little shelf of books. There were about 20 books on the whole thing. I had fallen into somewhat of a slump and was looking for something to read. On the first shelf, the vendor had the first two (really beat up) Harry Potter books. Despite having these recommended to me a million times and ignoring it, I just felt like I was in a good position to finally read these. SO GLAD I DID.



If you're someone like me who avoids hyped up books until the hype dies, make an exception here. PLEASE. The hype on this series is absolutely 100% valid and will more than likely never die. I'm not sure that J.K. Rowling knew she was writing a masterpiece that would live on forever, but she definitely did just that.

I'm not going to get into the synopsis because even if you've never read or seen the movies, odds are that you still know a lot about the series. Kind of like Star Wars. You can't escape it.

This series is a little bit of everything so no matter what genre or age, you're going to love it. A lot of people worry that it's childish. Yes, it is a children's book. However, that's just saying that it is appropriate for children and the main character is a child at the start of the series. However, there are a lot of complex pieces to the story that make it enjoyable for adults. A child can read it and understand what's happening and enjoy, but there are a lot of concepts that are really intriguing and better understood by an adult mind. It's literally the perfect story. I don't know how she did it.

Also, Harry is so much sassier in the books, so if you find him particularly funny in the movies, you're really missing out.



If you're still not sure about starting this series, just remember that I was you and since then, I've

-read all the books (multiple times)
-own at least $1,000 in Harry Potter merchandise
-Seen all the movies (and rewatch them once a month, usually when Freeform marathons them)
-Gone to A Celebration of Harry Potter every year since
-Met the illustrator of the books
-Gone to a panel to see some of the actors
-And even got a job working on the Hogwarts Express at Universal Orlando Resort.

And I'm sure there are a million other things but my point is, I didn't think I would like it and now my life basically is loving Harry Potter with an occasional mix of socializing and eating and sleeping.

Just read it. The first book is short and can be finished in a day. There's no reason to not at least make time for this one and test it out.

These books have a way of becoming a part of you. In a way that you just won't understand till you've experienced it.

 ...more

Nov 21, 2016 Samuel rated it it was amazing
I read this out loud with my wife (my second time reading it in my life, her fifth?). At first I was reluctant to re-read what I once read in Middle School--there is so much else I haven't read yet and I will surely be reading these out loud with my children someday--but I caved, and I was surprised by how much I enjoyed re-reading this modern children's classic. Starting a few days before Halloween, it seemed seasonally appropriate at first, but really it is a timeless tale that takes me I read this out loud with my wife (my second time reading it in my life, her fifth?). At first I was reluctant to re-read what I once read in Middle School--there is so much else I haven't read yet and I will surely be reading these out loud with my children someday--but I caved, and I was surprised by how much I enjoyed re-reading this modern children's classic. Starting a few days before Halloween, it seemed seasonally appropriate at first, but really it is a timeless tale that takes me literally back to my childhood (and perhaps all generations back to theirs figuratively). It is such a fun world that Rowling creates and it is so believable in the sense that she sets it in the real world but with a veil of secrecy protecting a knowledge of its existence from non-magic folks (known affectionately now as Muggles). The characters are lovable and rarely flat (though the Dursleys seem to resemble some of Roald Dahl's revolting, compassionless, Twit-like characters and the fact that only Slytherians defected to the Dark Side seems unbelievably one-dimentional). For the most part, however, the characters have big personalities that are capable of good, evil, and shades of grey. There are echoes of our common world in Rowling's magical world--sports, school subjects, capitalist banking, groups sorted into competing factions aware of status, class, ancestry--but they are coupled with a glorious magical veneer that makes them all the more exciting. In the end though, magic does not solve the world's problems, rather it replicates if not amplifies our world's vices--greed for power and wealth--and virtues--courage and love--and presents them in a clever and engaging manner.

There is in the character Harry Potter a common longing to be something great, but then--upon being told you are already something great and have great expectations (see Mormon theology concerning the pre-Earth life)--a fear of the inevitable disappointment you will be to many sets in. It is nice to see Harry be frustrated with this common human experience of grappling with the expectations of others and overcoming its crippling effects by investing in friendships that help him realize his self-worth on a scale of his own rather than the one handed to him by society. This theme develops further and repeatedly in the sequels, but its foundation is right here in the first installment. There truly is something magical to the world Rowling creates with words, and it was a delightful indulgence to re-visit it.

(Having played many games and sports, however, I still think the scoring in Quidditch is ridiculous, and should be revised--150 points for catching the Snitch (and ending the game) is way disproportionate to the 10 points gained by each scoring of the Quaffle, which seems to rarely occur more than 15 times per team per game and thus reduces the game to who catches the Snitch wins in all but the most ridiculous cases (if the point of the game is to win, why would a seeker ever catch the Snitch when his/her team is down more than 150 points). A possible alteration is that catching the Snitch ends the game for the team in the lead or it resets the scoreboard and the Snitch is re-released if caught by the trailing team so that both aspects of the game matter rather than just one over the other. And perhaps the three hoops could have varying points--most for the central hoop less for the adjacent hoops as it is easier to defend the central hoop than the other two. I guess what I am griping about--and have been for over a decade--is that this sport could have been further revised and developed to be a more satisfying game structurally). ...more

Apr 15, 2017 Liberty rated it it was amazing
As per usual, Harry Potter made it onto my TBR for a reread this year. And because I was doing a TBR for books I loved in high school I had to add this one in for a quick and easy read. Not to mention the sheer amount of nostalgia that pours into me every time I read this story. Ive been reading Harry Potter since I was in 5th grade so theres no way I could give an accurate star rating without any bias. Its at a 5 and itll stay at a 5 no matter how much J.K. Rowling tries to ruin my love for As per usual, Harry Potter made it onto my TBR for a reread this year. And because I was doing a TBR for books I loved in high school I had to add this one in for a quick and easy read. Not to mention the sheer amount of nostalgia that pours into me every time I read this story. I‚Äôve been reading Harry Potter since I was in 5th grade so there‚Äôs no way I could give an accurate star rating without any bias. It‚Äôs at a 5 and it‚Äôll stay at a 5 no matter how much J.K. Rowling tries to ruin my love for Harry Potter through her Twitter.

I‚Äôve been reading this series since I was 10 so for two-thirds of my life now I‚Äôve been living with these characters. But I think as I‚Äôve grown up this world has changed for me. I remember telling a friend that the world of Harry Potter feels less fanciful and silly than it used to. I don‚Äôt know if that comes from rereading the books for 20 years or from growing up but I was sad to discover that the world I‚Äôve always loved felt like it had changed for me. But reading the illustrated version really brought back so much of the silliness and awestruck wonder that I had been missing in my past few rereads of the series. I think if you‚Äôre someone who has grown up with Harry Potter then you definitely need to invest in a collection of the illustrated versions.

I will say that as a grown up I‚Äôm really struck by how much the adults are failing Harry throughout the series. From being dropped off on a porch in the middle of the night in late Fall to being allowed to go through with his plan to save the Sorcerer‚Äôs Stone. I know we‚Äôve all developed this sense that Dumbledore is purposefully putting Harry in these horrible situations to use him, but the sheer amount of shit Harry had to deal with in just book one broke my heart. I really wish I could have jumped into the story and saved Harry for the 10 years he had to endure with the Dursleys. Not to mention the times that Harry tried to warn adults about what was going on and them shrugging it off. I know it‚Äôs a children‚Äôs book so the adults are kind of supposed to be like that but as an adult I don‚Äôt think I could ever treat Harry the way he‚Äôs treated throughout the series.

As usual, I want nothing more than to dive deeper into this world and live at Hogwarts (I mean, isn‚Äôt that the dream?). If I have to endure the monsters to get to live in this world, I‚Äôll take it‚Äìin a heart beat, I‚Äôll take it. I‚Äôve loved the wizarding world for most of my life at this point and I cannot imagine not having it there to comfort myself with. The story holds up so well as it ages and that‚Äôs really rare. I still find that books that came out between 2006 to 2014 are pretty cringe-y and this book is almost 22 years old. That‚Äôs amazing. On top of the world building that just gets better and better as the series goes on. I just love it. ...more
